thread.section_title: Finance | Business and Finance News | News.com.au
thread.title: Colin Barnett will lead Libs for 2017 election, backs Uber taxi service
thread.title_full: Colin Barnett will lead Libs for 2017 election, backs Uber taxi service

author: KAITLYN OFFER
title: Colin Barnett will lead Libs for 2017 election, backs Uber taxi service
text:
WEST Australian Premier Colin Barnett has backed Uber, saying it was “here to stay’’ — on the same day the ride sharing service was fined $7.3 million in its home state of California for not complying with reporting obligations.
The company is also facing suspension following the judgement.
California Public Utilities Commission chief administrative law judge Karen V. Clopton found that Uber had not complied with the state’s laws to ensure all passengers were treated fairly.
Judge Clopton found Uber had failed to provide:
● Information on the number and percentage of customers who requested accessible vehicles for wheelchairs and service animals.
● Information on the number of rides requested and accepted, requested and not accepted, and fees paid, by postcode.
● Driver safety information, including the cause of any incidents drivers were involved in.
An Uber spokeswoman said the ruling and the associated fine were “deeply disappointing.”
The Uber app on a mobile phone Source: AFP
“We will appeal the decision as Uber has already provided substantial amounts of data to the California Public Utilities Commission, information we have provided elsewhere with no complaints,” she said.
“Going further risks compromising the privacy of individual riders as well as driver-partners. These CPUC requests are also beyond the authority of the Commission and will not improve public safety.”
Uber also faces suspension because of the ruling, but while its appeal is on foot, the suspension will not be enforced.
On Thursday morning, Premier Colin Barnett publicly backed Uber, saying he would be happy to use an Uber taxi.
“The reality that I have to face and the Transport Minister has to face is that people are using it, they find it an alternative service.”
Mr Barnett said the government “would like to somehow bring Uber within the law, maybe that means them adjusting, maybe it means the law adjusting, maybe it means the taxi industry adjusting.”
He also said the service would have to “play along” with regulation but that “Uber is here to stay, in one way or another”.
A spokeswoman said Mr Barnett would not have been aware of the judgement when the comments were made.
The Uber spokeswoman welcomed Mr Barnett’s comments.
“We’re also looking forward to seeing the Government’s Green Paper and moving forward with implementing sensible, safety-based ride-sharing regulations as quickly as possible,” she said.
Transport Minister Dean Nalder’s office said “No thanks” to commenting on the Californian judgment.
During his interview on ABC, Mr Barnett also confirmed his current term would be his last in parliament.
Colin Barnett: “Uber is here to stay, in one way or another.’’ Source: News Corp Australia
Originally published as Uber ‘here to stay’ amid $7.3m fine
